Title: Black Truffle Dry Brined Wagyu #shorts

Title: Trimming a Dry Aged Brisket #shorts
Transcript: trimming and preparing a dry aged brisket after 50 days notice the hard and dry exterior that we need to slice away the first thing i noticed was that some of the fat had turned green but still smelled okay notice that incredible marbling i then moved over to the flat leaving about a quarter of an inch of fat the bottom section i tried to remove only as much as necessary since there wasn't any fat protecting it unlike a fresh brisket the color of the red meat was extremely vivid and the fat was actually rendering at room temp this is one of the juiciest briskets i've ever cooked and the nutty blue cheese dry age flavor was still very apparent even after the 10 hours of smoking

Title: The Steak Review: The Outback #shorts
Transcript: this is the safe review and we're here at the outback bone-in ribeye medium rare also a blooming onion let's do it and set up shop using a sophisticated weighted formula we're on a mission to find the best steak in america so far i've had a great experience all the employees have been extremely nice in the bathroom solid so let's check out this steak overall we have a pretty decent char though a slight lack of consistency in the middle it's about a half an inch thick with a nice and defined cap muscle which is exactly what i'm looking for let's cut it to it so as you can see we have a perfect medium rare a little gray band but pretty minimal this is cooked almost perfectly not bad we're just doing a steak review oh no that's fine overall this is a pretty good steak definitely grilled over fire it is a little bit bland and could definitely use more salt and pepper blooming onion this tasted like a choice grade rib eye for 28 bucks that isn't bad but strong seasonings or even a sauce would have gone a long way in elevating the average meat quality the final score 73 out of 100

Title: Steak School: Beef Tenderloin #shorts
Transcript: welcome back to state school today we're learning about the beef tenderloin located up towards the rear the tenderloin is a non-weight-bearing muscle only responsible for back and forth movement and therefore extremely lean and tender to break down this unpeeled tenderloin you start by removing the wing which is great as a roast next remove the chain or psoas miner best reserved for ground and stew meat remove the silver skin this is the money maker the psoas major remove the tails and we have a chateaubriand perfect for a beef wellington though lean it's the most tender cut on the entire animal slice and we're left with beautiful filet mignons the exact same cut as the small side of the porterhouse prize and pricey for its tenderness the drawback is sometimes a lack in flavor in my opinion best serve rare a good crowd pleaser especially when it's on sale

Title: Duck & A Story #shorts
Transcript: as an american living in china i've had some pretty unique food experiences the options were extensive but the food was nothing like the chinese food i was used to no orange chicken or crab rangoons and not once did the meal end with a fortune cookie i was living off of steamed buns and late night barbecue skewers that i would pick up on my electric scooter believe it or not my favorite snack was pickled chicken feet i was quickly eating like a local not just because i needed to but also because i wanted to and it started with an open mind which i believe is the key to my happiness

Title: Wine Aged Ribeye #shorts
Transcript: red wine soaked dry aged prime rib wrap in cheesecloth and cover in a bottle of wine put that in the fridge and get ready for a nap three weeks later unwrap the mummified piece of meat and check out that incredible color slicing into it the smell is unbelievable slightly nutty with hints of red wine sear based slices through like butter but what matters most is the taste super tender definitely get that wine flavor i think we're onto something with this

Title: Steak School Pt. 2: Skirt Steak 101 #shorts
Transcript: welcome back to steak school today we're learning about the skirt steak two distinct cuts the more common inside skirt and prized outside skirt both from the rib and plate section starting with the outside skirt running from the bottom of the sixth to the top of the twelfth rib tender with tighter muscle fibers more pricey but worth it next is the less desirable inside skirt more common in stores tougher cheaper with more coarse muscle fibers i remember it as outside grilling is better than indoor so always choose the outside skirt extreme heat is critical because they're so thin charring the outside before overcooking the inside in this case i don't mind flare-ups carryover will be more than usual due to the intense heat i like to pull the outside at 110 inside at 120 the most important step is to cut thinly against the grain cooked properly these beefy cuts are hard to beat

Title: WAGYU Beef Jerky? #shorts
Transcript: today i made a whole bunch of homemade beef jerky that's way cheaper and so much better than store bought here's how jerky is traditionally used with lean cuts but today i'm going for optimal flavor find the grain of the meat and cut against it i like my slices about a quarter of an inch thick the ratio of our salty ingredients to our sugar is by far the most important today i'm making a black pepper original and sesame ginger teriyaki mix well i like to test for any necessary changes oh yeah marinade overnight then load up your racks dehydrators smokers and even an oven will work after five hours this is the result beautiful glossy exterior and a pull apart texture only blackhawk farms wagyu can achieve serve with a bev this is real deal beef jerky wow

Title: Steak School: Ribeye 101 in 60 Seconds #shorts
Transcript: welcome to state school today we're learning about the rib eye rib eyes are a premium cut characterized by two distinct sides with the first directly adjacent to the chuck or shoulder this side has four unique components the first is the eye or longest miss dorsey though tender it's the least beefy so make sure it has good marbling next is the rib eye cap or spineless dorsi considered the most desirable cut on the animal beefy tender always try to find a rib eye with a big and thick cap the third is the complexis as an extension of the chuck muscle this is going to be a little bit more tough and less desirable lastly we have the rib and tail section nothing beats these bites right off the bone next we have the lowing end of the rib eye directly adjacent to the strip line this cut is made up of just the longest miss dorsey essentially just the extension of the new york strip in my opinion anywhere in the one third closest to the chuck is the sweet spot this cut is hard to beat

Title: Filet Mignon STEAK EXPERIMENT #shorts
Transcript: today we're combining dry aged wagyu a5 fat with a filet mignon we're starting with two identical filet mignons this is a hundred day dry aged a5 beef fat that is liquid gold tenderloin can be lean lacking flavor inject one with as much artificial marbling as possible in this case 20 extra grams i'm interested in seeing how much weight was retained after the cooking process despite the drastically different starting weights interestingly they both ended at the same final weight but cutting into them was where the real differences were found the injected stake on the right had noticeable holes but it was a significantly better final product it had the tenderness of a filet and the flavor of a rip eye that one has a lot more flavor can definitely taste the fat

Title: Is DRY BRINING Worth It? Steak Science #shorts
Transcript: many chefs swear by dry grinding their steaks with salt today we're gonna see if it's worth it i started with two identical steaks season one with three and a half grams of salt and dried rhine overnight dark and dry exterior on the dry brine stay compared to the non-dry brine season the next right before cooking on an even temperature pan as we flip notice how the dry brine steak is a dark mahogany color normal steaks crust is less pronounced butter baste and pull both at 125 notice the significantly better crust on the dry brine steak on the right the dry brine steak also retained an extra 3 grams of moisture visually they both passed the squeeze test appreciate the follow on ig if you've gotten value from this content overall both steaks were great the drive brine did beat it up slightly on crust and flavor not a huge difference but if you have time definitely go for the dry brine
